Huang Zunxian (1848-1905), Qing dynasty poet and diplomat, author of A Record of Japan 日本國誌|日本国志[Ri4 ben3 Guo2 zhi4], an extended analysis of Meiji Japan
Wei Yuan (1794-1857), Qing dynasty thinker, historian and scholar
Xue Fucheng (1838-1894), Qing official and progressive political theorist
Zhang Yinhuan (1837-1900), late Qing politician and senior Chinese diplomat
Lin Shu (1852-1924), writer and influential translator and adaptor of vast swathes of Western literature into Classical Chinese
Fukuzawa Yukichi (1835-1901), prominent Japanese Westernizer, liberal educator and founder of Keio University
to compose (a piece of writing)/to write/(written) work/writer
Yan Fu (1853-1921), influential Chinese writer and translator of Western books, esp. on social sciences
Cai Dongfan (1877-1945), historian and historical novelist
Liang Qichao (1873-1929), influential journalist and a leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Xu Jiyu (1795-1873), Chinese geographer

Kang Youwei (1858-1927), Confucian intellectual, educator and would-be reformer, main leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
